column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0140] The probability of eliminating P terms, P.sub.e(.psi.), can be estimated based on its past experience of the learner process.

#Text=For each sample the learner process presents, a record can be created which sets forth how many disjunctions the sample contradicts with respect to the query concept and whether the sample is labeled positive.
#Text=Once a sufficient amount of data has been collected, we can estimate P.sub.e(.psi.) empirically.
#Text=We then pick the .psi.* that can eliminate the maximum expected number of disjunctive terms.

#Text=[0141] Again, a reasonable approach to estimate P.sub.e(.psi.) is to use probabilistic estimation when the learner process first starts and then to switch to empirical estimation when the sufficient data has been collected.
#Text=The transition from probabilistic estimation to empirical estimation takes place gradually and only after numerous users have employed the query-concept learner process.
#Text=This transition does not occur during the course of a single user session.
#Text=[0142] Moreover, an abrupt transition from one estimation approach to the other could be problematic, since the two estimates of P.sub.e(.psi.) may differ substantially.
#Text=This could lead to a sudden change in behavior of the sampling component of the active learner.
#Text=To remedy this problem, we employ a Bayesian smoothing approach.
#Text=Essentially the probabilistic estimation is the prior guess at the distribution over .psi. and the empirical approach is the guess based purely on the data that has been gathered so far.
#Text=The Bayesian approach combines both of these guesses in a principled manner.
#Text=Before we start, we imagine that we have seen a number of samples of .psi..
#Text=After refinement iteration, we gather new samples for .psi.; then we add them to our current samples and adjust P.sub.e(.psi.).

#Text=[0143] For example, before we start, we assume that we have already seen samples with .psi.=1 being labeled positive three out of five times and samples with .psi.=2 being labeled positive seven out of 20 times.
#Text=In other words, we have successfully eliminated .psi.=1 term three times out of five, and we have successfully eliminated .psi.=2 terms 7 times out of 20.
#Text=Thus initially P.sub.e(.psi.=1)=3/5=0.6 and P(.psi.=2)={fraction (7/20)}=0.35.
#Text=Now suppose we do a query and in which we observe a sample with, .psi.=2 being labeled positive.
#Text=Then our new distribution is P(.psi.=1)=3/5 and P(.psi.=2)={fraction (8/21)}.
#Text=We continue in this manner.
#Text=At first, the prior assumption has quite an effect on our guess about the distribution.
#Text=The more imaginary samples we have in our prior assumption, the larger its effect.

#Text=For instance, if we assume that .psi.-1 being labeled positive 30 out of 50 times and that .psi.=2 being labeled positive 70 out of 200 times, it takes more real samples to change P.sub.e(.psi.).
#Text=With time, the more real samples we get, the less the effect of the prior assumption becomes, until eventually it has virtually no effect, and the observed data dominate the expression.
#Text=This procedure gives us a smooth transition between the "probabilistic" and the "empirical" methods.
#Text=[0144] 2.3 Refinement
